bibl.title: Letter from Robert P. Cooke to Philip Showalter Hench, March 18, 1941

div1.p: Cooke approves Hench's report on his investigation of the actual site of Camp Lazear. He feels that the definite proof of the exact location, and its preparation as a memorial to the Yellow Fever Commission, is a valuable historic achievement. An attached autograph note provides physical details of the site.

div1.head: Letter from Robert P. Cooke to Philip Showalter Hench, March 18, 1941
div1.opener:
COMMONWEALTH OF VIRGINIA
STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
LEXINGTON-ROCKBRIDGE HEALTH DEPARTMENT
LEXINGTON, VIRGINIA
March 18th, 1941
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Please pardon my delay in returning your report on
your investigation of the site of Camp Lazear, but I have
not, until now, been able to find time from my duties to
go over the papers as carefully as I wanted to. So far
as my memory goes your conclusions are essentially correct
in all details and I congratulate you on the thoroughness
and persistence with which you have conducted the inves-
tigation. Such definite proof of the exact location and
its preparation as a memorial to the Commission is a val-
uable historic achievement. Trusting your trip will be
a very enjoyable one.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Robert P. Cooke The stove was, I am sure,
on the left as you enter
and the whole Camp
Site? was bare of trees
Certainly there were none
near the experimental
buildings R. P. C.
